TimeInterview: Well this is kind of like a timeline, really, so ‘past’ I think as being inherently to the left, and the future being to the right. That might link with our reading and the way we read, so we start at the left hand side of the page and move to the right, and what’s on the right side of the page is in the future - what’s coming up in the story, sort of thing. And also on general timelines they seem to be in that order anyway, like historical timelines, they’re generally organised left to right. They don’t go to the future but the present; the more recent events are on the right.
QuantityInterview: That was my initial response - that I should put it furthest to the left at the bottom, being the least, and furthest to the top on the right… although I did put it slightly in there, but I realised as soon as I put it a little bit further down that it actually should be in the extreme, the furthest it can be, right at the top, so they’re completely poles apart. I was aiming for that top right-hand corner anyway, but I’m not sure I wrote that one first or not. ValenceInterview: This was the same as the least and the most. I didn’t put it there horizontally because that’s further away. It’s similar to a mathematical quadrant graph where you’ve got negative and negative on the bottom left, and then positive and positive on the top right, so it’s that as well - the fact that it’s worse and worse - really really bad, and that’s the worst it can possibly be. In fact, if you put numbers on this that would be the highest negative value that you could get, and same with the positive.

TimeInterview: I didn’t think the height was necessary so I thought I’d write along the line - I was thinking about the other two; we had ‘most’ and ‘least’ which I felt like may dictate height or the way you actually put it, whereas with ‘past’ and ‘future’ it doesn’t seem like something you’d think about in terms of where you’re putting it. It’s more about the distance away from each other, again, so I thought that putting it on the line was fine. QuantityInterview: As you can see, I actually crossed it out - I put that top left first, because I thought, again, that writing from left to right… But then I actually thought about that if you write one to ten, you start with one on the left-hand side, with ten being on the right-hand side, and so I thought the same thing. I thought ‘wait a minute’, so if one is the least then I’ll put it on the left, so that’s why I put L there and why I put M on the right-hand side.
ValenceInterview: I do to an extent. I know I wanted to put ‘best’ towards the top and worst towards the bottom. Why I did left to right… I thought they were the furthest away from each other. TimeInterview: There’s a timeline that I’d associate with that line, so the future always goes at the front, towards the right and the past is always towards the left.
QuantityInterview: Normally when you see a graph or a bar chart or whatever, you always see… I think least and most is to do with quantity, and the higher quantity always goes at the top and the low at the bottom. ValenceInterview: Similar to the first one, the ‘best’ is known as bringing about the highest or happiest emotions, which you would associate with being at the top, and the worst is associated with bad things which you would associate with being quite low and towards the bottom.

TimeInterview: In my head I thought of a timeline; obviously the future is the furthest and the past is earlier on on an axis.
QuantityInterview: If you put it in a box… top right is the highest point and bottom left is the lowest point of the box, and the highest point is the ‘most’ and the ‘least’ is there. TimeInterview: I tend to think of ‘past’ as being behind you, so if you’re going forward, being as I’m right-handed I see forward as going towards the right into the future, and left would be into the past.

ValenceInterview: The best - ‘cause obviously [the top right quadrant is] the furthest point you can get to in terms of height and distance, whereas with ‘worst’ that’s the furthest away you can get to it. I see the horizontal as distance and the vertical as height.

TimeInterview: Past I put in the furthest left that it could be, because to me the past is behind me, and future is as far to the right that it could be. QuantityInterview: Because this one’s a bit more ambiguous, I’ve put least in the bottom left and most in the top right, because I guess that’s the lowest point in that side and that’s the lowest point on that side, typically, so you’d think the most is… If you’re thinking about this sort of graph and axes - let’s use an example of a cake. Say this axis is large and that’s taste, most intense is going to be the biggest and tastiest cake, but the least is going to be the smallest and the crappiest one.
ValenceInterview: I guess you can apply a similar principle to that one [most vs. least], so with worst there can be multiple attributes to something that’s worst and that’s why it’s not on a particular axis, and same for best - there could be multiple reasons why they’re the best.

TimeInterview: Because I see future and past on a line like that, and past being before and future after, so that’s why I chose that one.
QuantityInterview: I didn’t know about this one - I was like… I don’t know, I just put it on the same line as that one, with the least being less and most being more, so I just thought that’d be like that. So I see least as left - I don’t know why. It might be because I’m right handed.
ValenceInterview: I dunno, I see it as a line - up and down. Like worst is when you’re going down - I think it’s linked to worst being down, feeling down and stuff like that. TimeInterview: Just because it’s moving on an x axis. It’s how I’d visualise the movement of time. I don’t really know why that is. Because there’s an inability to move backwards or forwards - it’s just completely linear, so it’s moving on an x axis.
QuantityInterview: Again, very similar to better and worst. It’s more being an increase in positive numbers across the axis, and least being a decrease in negative numbers across the axis. There wasn’t any reason why I drew the numbers in the middle - just habit. It just looked better on the page.
ValenceInterview: I just saw it as a positive and a negative, so as you move into the positive you’re getting better, so you’re moving upwards, and moving into the negative you’d be going down, decreasing along the axis. TimeInterview: For past and future I’ve done past near the bottom left because it’s at a distance, so it’s like, say past is something that’s already done, so it’s buried in the bottom corner, whereas future is at an angle. It’s a bit like, do you know you have a product life, where it’s going in a diagonal? In like, say, business studies they have product lives where you have a graph, and it shows a progression, and sometimes it’s just like a straight diagonal line, so I’ve done that with past and future, so past is going below the zero where it’s already done, and future’s keep going the top of the chart diagonal, so that’s why I’ve done it kind of diagonal to each other and past at the bottom and future on the top.
QuantityInterview: For most and least, I dunno… I think it was just natural. I just done M and L next to each other, but it’s… I dunno, it’s hard to explain. I dunno. I just did it out of the blue right next to each other, and it’s just how to explain. Sorry about that.
ValenceInterview: I think it’s like a scale, so it’s like d’you know when you go higher and lower? I would have done it in one of these two and then worst in these two. It didn’t matter to me which of the quadrants it was in. I probably should have done it across the line. Yeah, either one of these two or one of them two, just to show the scale – best should be on top of worst.

TimeInterview: Because we read left to right. You assume left is past, right’s forward. Same with video games – left to right, it’s always left to right, unless you’re in the middle east, and it’s right to left.
QuantityInterview: Pretty much the same reason: left-right, left is less – it’s something you don’t really have to think about; right’s more, it’s a progression. Future, more, more time.

It’s the same reason really: past-future, it’s visual, left-right. We’re Western. It’s how we read, how we watch stuff.

TimeInterview: Kind of like because on a timeline, past is always gonna be further left and present and future is gonna be further right so just left and right for past and future.
QuantityInterview: Just because least is generally lower and most is higher, so I put least at the bottom and most at the top. Because of how it’s used in terms of, you say if something’s the most, it’s gonna be high or good or the best, whereas least is always going to be the worst or the lowest.
ValenceInterview: Kind of like ‘cause it’s on a chart, so in a graph, the worst is probably lower on, whereas best is higher up in a graph, presuming both sides are like… so I always think of the best as up here and the worst as lower and left.

TimeInterview: I don’t really know. It just seemed like two extremes. So I guess I maybe visualised the present in the centre, so you just move away. ValenceInterview: Because I always think with best, when you put it on a scale, best is always on the top and then worst is on the bottom, so I think that’s just how I think of it. On a scale.

ValenceInterview: So the best I was thinking at the top but also first, so best in top left and then worst is obviously opposite so bottom right.
